com.example.components

Class VerticalProgressBar

  • java.lang.Object
    • View
      • com.example.components.VerticalProgressBar

  • public class VerticalProgressBar
extends View
    VerticalProgressBar is a class that implements vertical progress bar that we can add to the application view.
    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    v5.0
    Author:
    Shmulik Melamed, Lital Motola

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      VerticalProgressBar(Context context)
      Create a new progress bar with range 0...100 and initial progress of 0.
      VerticalProgressBar(Context context, AttributeSet attrs)
      Added in API level 1 Create a new progress bar with range 0...100 and initial progress that the user decide.
      VerticalProgressBar(Context context, AttributeSet attrs, int defStyle)
      Added in API level 1 Create a new progress bar with range 0...100 and initial progress that the user decide, and the progress bar style.

      • postInvalidate

        public void postInvalidate()
        Added in API level 1 Cause an invalidate to happen on a subsequent cycle through the event loop. Use this to invalidate the View from a non-UI thread. This method can be invoked from outside of the UI thread only when this View is attached to a window.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        #invalidate(), #postInvalidateDelayed(long)

      • onSaveInstanceState

        public Parcelable onSaveInstanceState()
        Added in API level 1 Hook allowing a view to generate a representation of its internal state that can later be used to create a new instance with that same state. This state should only contain information that is not persistent or can not be reconstructed later. For example, you will never store your current position on screen because that will be computed again when a new instance of the view is placed in its view hierarchy. Some examples of things you may store here: the current cursor position in a text view (but usually not the text itself since that is stored in a content provider or other persistent storage), the currently selected item in a list view.
        Returns:
        Returns a Parcelable object containing the view's current dynamic state, or null if there is nothing interesting to save. The default implementation returns null.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        #onRestoreInstanceState(android.os.Parcelable), #saveHierarchyState(android.util.SparseArray), #dispatchSaveInstanceState(android.util.SparseArray), #setSaveEnabled(boolean)

      • onRestoreInstanceState

        public void onRestoreInstanceState(Parcelable state)
        Added in API level 1 Hook allowing a view to re-apply a representation of its internal state that had previously been generated by onSaveInstanceState(). This function will never be called with a null state.
        Parameters:
        state - The frozen state that had previously been returned by onSaveInstanceState().
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        onSaveInstanceState(), #restoreHierarchyState(android.util.SparseArray), #dispatchRestoreInstanceState(android.util.SparseArray)
